Notification Exercises:
In response to the requirements set forth in 40 CFR 68.96(a), Rinchem has developed procedures to conduct an exercise of the stationary source's emergency response notification mechanisms.  As all Rinchem Company, LLC facilities are non-responding stationary sources, Rinchem management and EHS recognize the importance of communication to emergency response organizations that hazards that are present at Rinchem facilities.  Rinchem has, and will continue to send community outreach letters to emergency response organizations (LEPC, Fire and Police) and invite these organizations to tour our stationary sources and participate in  accidental release drills. 
1.6 Planned changes to improve safety:
The facility evaluates, resolves, and implements employee suggestions and recommendations resulting from routine hazard reviews, audits, process hazard analyses, and incident 
investigations. Changes may be made to improve safety based on comments and information developed within our organization and the industry. Rinchem is always looking at ways to minimize risk through process improvement, upgrades to equipment used in the process, and review of operating procedures.

1.3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 
Rinchem management realizes that implementation of appropriate administrative and technological safeguards ensure the safety of the workers and the continued safety of public receptors. Those recommendations that are planned for implementation will be discussed in Planned Changes to Improve Safety. The safeguards include both administrative and technological safeguards that prevent, detect, or mitigate releases of arsine, chlorine, fluorine and anhydrous hydrochloric acid.
1.4. The Five Year Accident History
There has never been a reportable accident involving RMP regulated substances or any other chemical any Rinchem Company, LLC warehouses.
1.5. The Emergency Action Program
Overall safety at the Rinchem Company, LLC, Surprise, AZ warehouse is governed not only by our ability to prevent accidental releases of arsine, chlorine, fluorine, and anhydrous hydrochloric acid from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases of the abovementioned materials. Rinchem has developed an emergency action program to minimize the effects of accidental releases of arsine, chlorine, fluorine, and anhydrous hydrochloric acid to employees. Rinchem management has opted to respond to releases of these chemicals by using contracted services for emergency response and spill cleanup. The Surprise warehouse Emergency Action Program consists of a Business Continuity Plan and facility-specific Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Program outlines the instructions and required information in order to respond to fire, chemical spills, natural disasters and other emergencies that may arise. The Emergency action plan and documents are reviewed at least annually and revised as necessary to reflect changes that may occur to content an

others. Staff members, being the most familiar with actual operations, are responsible to document suggestions for continual improvements. Each employee is granted the authority to stop work if it is deemed unsafe. The job will not be continued until the work methods are evaluated and changed, if necessary, to make the work area safe. Management continues to do all it can to protect the Health and Safety of all staff and to provide a safe working environment. However, safety requires the participation of everyone...only you can
make safety a reality. Be alert for conditions which appear unsafe. Report unsafe conditions immediately, Report any accident, near miss, exposure, incident, spill or release.
1.2. A Description of the Surprise, AZ. Facility and Regulated Substances Handled
1.2.1. Description of the Surprise, AZ. Facility
The Surprise, AZ. facility is located at 13255 West Sweetwater Ave., Surprise, AZ. The facility provides transportation and warehousing services for manufacturers, distributors and end
users of pre-packaged specialty chemicals. Warehousing activities include shipping, receiving and storage of chemicals as specified by customer requirements. The chemicals stored at the Surprise, AZ. warehouse include chemicals containing toxic hazards. Arsine, chlorine, fluorine and anhydrous hydrogen chloride are the RMP regulated substances handled at the site.
1.2.2. Description of the Warehousing and Storage Processes
Rinchem receives various size cylinders of specialty gases by truck as shipped from the manufacturer or distributor. Cylinders are unloaded from the truck using a forklift or dollies and staged for inspection. After the storage vessels pass quality and safety inspection, they placed into the hazard-specific storage area until they are shipped to the end user. 1.0 Executive Summary
1.1. The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Action Policies at the Rinchem Company, LLC. Surprise, AZ Facility
Rinchem Company, LLC. (Rinchem) is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. Policy dictates that Rinchem personnel
continuously identify methods to reduce the risk of handling hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of new technology and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound
operations is documented in the Employee Handbook, and the mission statement, which are available to all employees.
The Safety and Health policy states: SAFETY FIRST is more than a slogan at Rinchem...it is a way of life. Rinchem Company, LLC is committed to providing a safe working environment for its staff members, its customers and the public, and maintains that NO JOB IS MORE IMPORTANT THAN THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF OUR STAFF MEMBERS,OUR COMMUNITIES, ANDTHE ENVIRONMENT.
We recognize that the responsibilities for safety and health are shared: Management, in particular the VP of Operations, Directors, and Corporate EHS accepts the responsibility for leadership of the safety and health program, for its effectiveness and improvement, and
for providing the safeguards required to ensure safe conditions. Operations managers and supervisors are responsible for ensuring processes are documented which reinforce safety as well as the use of engineering controls as the preferred method of promoting safety and eliminating unsafe conditions. Staff members are responsible for cooperation with all aspects of the safety and health program including compliance with all rules, documented procedures, and regulations and for continuously practicing safety while performing their duties.
